Article Title: Foreign Secretary Meeting: Dhaka-Delhi foreign secretary talks in December; Sheikh Hasina's extradition on the table?
Article Text: DHAKA: Bangladesh and India are preparing for a foreign secretary-level meeting in Dhaka during which the potential extradition of ex-PM Sheikh Hasina, at present in India, could be discussed. The meeting is scheduled in early Dec.Bangladesh foreign affairs ministry public diplomacy wing director-general Toufique Hasan said Thursday an inter-ministerial meeting was held at the ministry to prepare for the upcoming discussions.The foreign office consultations will be led by Bangladesh foreign secretary Md Jashim Uddin and his Indian counterpart Vikram Misri. The meeting is expected to cover a range of bilateral issues and Hasan said "there is scope for discussion on the matter (extradition of Hasina)".Hasina, who fled Dhaka on Aug 5 and has been in India since, is facing trial in Bangladesh's International Crimes Tribunal for her alleged involvement in mass killings during the July-Aug uprising.While Bangladesh's interim govt seeks her return, Hasan clarified that the foreign affairs ministry hasn't yet received any formal directive to begin the extradition process. "We will engage with Delhi and initiate the formal process in accordance with the existing extradition treaty once we receive the necessary instructions," he said.
Article Summary: Bangladesh and India preparing for a foreign secretary-level meeting in Dhaka. The potential extradition of ex-PM Sheikh Hasina, at present in India, could be discussed. Hasina is facing trial in Bangladesh's International Crimes Tribunal for her alleged involvement in mass killings during the July-Aug uprising.

Article Title: Elon Musk, Vivek Ramaswamy want 5-day in-office work week for govt staff
Article Text: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, the co-leaders of what President-elect Donald Trump has called the department of govt efficiency, said Wednesday they supported requiring federal employees to work from the office five days a week as part of a broad overhaul of the civil service.The change, they wrote in an opinion column in Wall Street Journal, could result in a "wave of voluntary terminations that we welcome.""If federal employees don't want to show up, American taxpayers shouldn't pay them for the Covid-era privilege of staying home," they wrote.In their column, Musk and Ramaswamy described some of the early aims of the department, which Trump had said would operate outside of the govt and offer input to federal officials. Musk has promised to eliminate $2 trillion from the annual US budget, and has said the govt needs only 99 agencies, not more than 400.Part of the group's task - cutting down the number of federal regulations - would be providing "sound industrial logic for mass head-count reductions across the federal bureaucracy," Musk and Ramaswamy wrote. The men have been advising Trump's transition team to hire what they said were "small-govt crusaders" to work with the White House's Office of Management and Budget.To accomplish the reductions, Musk and Ramaswamy wrote, federal appointees working with the efficiency department would identify a minimum number of employees to perform "constitutionally permissible and statutorily mandated functions," with the number of workers cut proportionate to the number of regulations scrapped.Ramaswamy has already outlined his support for five-day work weeks at federal agencies, telling Tucker Carlson recently such a mandate can lead to a "25% thinning out of the federal bureaucracy."A report issued earlier this year by the Office of Management and Budget found that federal employees who were eligible to work remotely were still spending more than 60% of their work hours in offices. Of the 2.3 million civilian workers working for the govt in May, the report said, 1.1 million were eligible for telework and about 228,000 were eligible for entirely remote work."Employees whose positions are eliminated deserve to be treated with respect," Musk and Ramaswamy wrote, adding that the efficiency department would "help support their transition into the private sector." "The president can use existing laws to give them incentives for early retirement and to make voluntary severance payments to facilitate a graceful exit," they wrote. nyt
Article Summary: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy are co-leaders of what President-elect Donald Trump has called the department of govt efficiency. The men have been advising Trump's transition team to hire what they said were "small-govt crusaders" to work with the White House's Office of Management and Budget.

Article Title: Justin Trudeau to cut sales tax and send checks to millions of Canadians as election looms
Article Text:
Justin Trudeau (AP file photo)

HALIFAX: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau 's government announced plans Thursday to temporarily lift the federal sales tax off a number of items and send checks to millions of Canadians who are dealing with rising costs and as a federal election looms.The measures come as a cost of living crisis has left voters unhappy with Trudeau and ahead of an election that could come anytime between this fall and next October."Our government can't set prices at the checkout, but we can put more money in people's pockets," Trudeau said at a news conference in Toronto.Under the plan, Canadians who worked in 2023 and earned up to 150,000 Canadian dollars ($ 107,440) will receive a check for 250 Canadian dollars. Trudeau noted that even those earning at the high end of that amount have been struggling to get by.An estimated 18.7 million Canadians will receive the one-time check.The federal goods and services tax break would begin Dec. 14 and end Feb. 15.The government said the tax break will apply to a number of items including children's clothing and shoes, toys, diapers, restaurant meals, beer and wine. It also applies to Christmas trees, a variety of snack foods and beverages and video game consoles.Opposition Conservative leader Pierre Poilievre called the announcement a "two month temporary tax trick" that won't make up for carbon taxes that are set to go up.Trudeau has said he will lead his Liberal Party into the next election, which could come anytime up to next October. No Canadian prime minister in more than a century has won four straight terms.Trudeau channeled the star power of his father in 2015 when he reasserted the country's liberal identity in 2015 after almost 10 years of Conservative rule. But the son of late Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau is now in trouble. Canadians have been frustrated by the cost of living coming out of the Covid-19 pandemic.The Liberals trail the opposition Conservatives 39% to 26% in the latest Nanos poll. The poll of 1,047 respondents has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points."Politically, it's probably too little too late and it feels like a desperate move on the part of an unpopular government," said Daniel Beland, a political science professor at McGill University in Montreal. "It's also bad public policy, at least from a fiscal standpoint."
Article Summary: An estimated 18.7 million Canadians will receive the one-time check. The federal goods and services tax break would begin Dec. 14 and end Feb. 15. Canadians have been frustrated by the cost of living coming out of the Covid-19 pandemic.

Article Title: Madhya Pradesh CM Mohan Yadav lays foundation stone of Rs 592 crore ‘medicity’ in Ujjain
Article Text:
Madhya Pradesh CM Mohan Yadav

‘Foreigners coming to Indore for treatment’

UJJAIN: Madhya Pradesh chief minister Mohan Yadav on Thursday performed ‘ bhoomi pujan ’ of the state's first 'medicity' in Ujjain. The proposed medicity will come on 14.97 acre land and will be built at an estimated cost of Rs 592.30 crore. On the occasion, CM Yadav also laid the foundation stone for a medical college in the temple town, which will be the 17th medical college in the state.While addressing the gathering, the chief minister said, "The initiative would not only elevate Ujjain's healthcare facilities but also make the city a high-tech medical hub in central India. This ambitious project is targeted to be completed before 2028 Simhastha Kumbh in Ujjain, during which about 15 crore people are expected to visit the city.Even in normal times, some 5-7 crore people visit Ujjain annually. The medicity will be hugely helpful," Yadav said.A medical device park is also being developed, with 950 acres of land in Vikram Udyogpuri being utilised, and an additional 950 acres being acquired. Major industrialists and investors are coming, and this trend will continue, he said, adding that efforts are being made to provide maximum facilities in minimal space.If more land is needed for the medical city in the future, it is available, he said. He noted that from 1956 to the present, only six medical colleges, including Raipur, were established in the state, but under the BJP's ideology, 17 govt medical colleges have been established, along with 13 private ones. Twelve medical colleges are coming up under the PPP model with plans to increase this to 10,000 in the coming years. Five Ayurvedic colleges will start this session, with seven more in the next session.He also mentioned the growth of medical tourism in the state, with people from abroad coming to places like Indore for treatment. The govt is prioritising the expansion of this sector. While people abroad have medical insurance, they often face long waits for treatment, which they receive promptly here.Air ambulances are working effectively in the state, with 24-hour service available in Rewa, Mahakoshal, and Vindhya. The campus will feature a high-rise building designed to maximize space utilization, with residential accommodation for doctors, paramedics, he added.
Article Summary: Madhya Pradesh chief minister Mohan Yadav on Thursday performed ‘ bhoomi pujan ’ of the state's first'medicity' in Ujjain. The proposed medicity will come on 14.97 acre land and will be built at an estimated cost of Rs 592.30 crore.

Article Title: Adani Group indictment: Cash pile covers 30 months, default risk low
Article Text: MUMBAI: Bankers say that the Adani Group may have to go slow on investments for now, given that global capital markets are currently not an option. Domestic banks may also find it difficult to advance fresh loans to projects where the directors are under investigation.The Adani group has a total debt of Rs 2.4 lakh crore, against which it has a cash balance of Rs 59,791 crore, resulting in net debt of Rs 1,81,604 crore. The cash balances are 24.77% of gross debt, providing it with enough liquidity cover to support 30 months of debt repayment . Lenders, therefore, do not foresee any immediate risk to loan repayments.Of the total gross debt, Rs 88,100 crore (36% of the exposure) is with domestic banks and institutions. The bulk of these domestic advances (Rs 75,877 crore) are term loans, while Rs 12,233 crore has been raised by way of working capital.Public sector banks have a 15% share of the total debt, while private banks have a 4% share. The largest domestic chunk - 18% of total debt - is held by public sector financial institutions and non-bank finance companies lending to the power and infrastructure segment.While global banks account for 26% of total debt, international capital markets by way of bonds are the largest creditors to the group at 29%. Domestic capital markets' share stood at 5% of total debt.Shares of Power Finance Corporation and Life Insurance Corporation, which have significant exposure to the Adani group, were down 3.5% and 1.6%, respectively.Institutions with large debt exposure to the Adani group include LIC, SBI, Power Finance Corporation, and Rural Electrification Corporation.The group, in an investor presentation after the first quarter, said that while its gross debt rose consistently from Rs 2.27 lakh crore in FY23 to Rs 2.41 lakh crore in FY24, the net debt has shrunk from Rs 1.87 lakh crore to Rs 1.81 lakh crore in FY24 due to improvements in cash balances. This followed a jump in earnings coupled with equity mobilisation by the group.
Article Summary: The Adani group has a total debt of Rs 2.4 lakh crore, against which it has a cash balance of Rs 59,791 crore. The cash balances are 24.77% of gross debt, providing it with enough liquidity cover to support 30 months of debt repayment. Lenders do not foresee any immediate risk to loan repayments.

Article Title: Adani Group indictment: 'Ex-Canada pension fund executives too paid bribes for solar projects'
Article Text: MUMBAI: Three former executives of Canada's second-largest pension fund administrator CDPQ, including a previous India head, face legal proceedings as part of a broad US prosecution. The charges allege that Adani Group's chairman Gautam Adani ran a large-scale bribery operation with Indian govt officials to obtain renewable energy contracts valued at billions of dollars.The three former executives are Saurabh Agarwal, who led CDPQ's India operations, Deepak Malhotra, who supervised the fund's infrastructure vertical for South Asia, and Cyril Cabanes, who led the infrastructure vertical for the Asia Pacific region.US authorities indicate that Cabanes, whilst serving as a director at CDPQ's India-based portfolio company Azure Power Global , participated in arranging bribes to Indian officials for solar power contracts. Adani Green, controlled by Gautam Adani, was also implicated in the bribery arrangement for securing solar power projects.Azure and Adani Green bagged significant contracts from Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI) under the Indian govt's manufacturing-linked scheme. US prosecutors additionally implicated Azure's former CEO Ranjit Gupta and previous chief strategist Rupesh Agarwal in the bribery scheme.Azure, previously listed on the New York Stock Exchange, was delisted in 2023. The NYSE initiated delisting procedures in July 2023 when Azure failed to submit required regulatory documentation. Despite Azure's attempts to reverse the decision and submit outstanding paperwork, the shares were removed from trading on Nov 13, 2023.CDPQ, which established its Indian presence in 2016 with investments exceeding $7 billion, acknowledged the US charges against its former employees. It said that those employees were dismissed in 2023 and that it is cooperating with US authorities in their investigation.
Article Summary: Three former executives of Canada's second-largest pension fund administrator CDPQ face legal proceedings as part of a broad US prosecution. The charges allege that Adani Group's chairman Gautam Adani ran a large-scale bribery operation with Indian govt officials.

Article Title: Rs 18,948 crore at stake: Poll delays put Karnataka's central funds in jeopardy
Article Text:
Issue across various

local bodies

Anti-incumbency risk for congress govt

BENGALURU: Karnataka faces a severe financial setback as prolonged delays in elections for zilla panchayats (ZPs), taluk panchayats (TPs), and urban local bodies (ULBs), including the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike , jeopardize its eligibility for central grants. The state has just 16 months to complete these polls or risk losing a huge share of Rs 18,948 crore allocated by the 15th Finance Commission for 2021-26.Of the total grant, Rs 12,539 crore is earmarked for rural local bodies (RLBs) and Rs 6,409 crore for ULBs, distributed in a 65:35 ratio. However, the Union finance ministry has withheld Rs 2,842 crore, or 15% of the 2023-24 allocation, citing delays in local body elections. While gram panchayats, which remain functional, have received their share, funds for zilla panchayats, taluk panchayats, and BBMP are frozen as these councils ceased to exist after their tenures expired.The elections for BBMP, pending since Sept 2021, and for ZPs and TPs, overdue since May 2022, remain stalled. Meanwhile, polls for Shivamogga Mahanagara Palike and Mysuru City Corporation were only completed in Nov 2023, and Tumkur and Davanagere city corporations face deadlines in Jan 2024 and Feb 2025, respectively."We could not claim funds for ZPs and TPs since these local bodies don't exist after their councils' tenure expired. Efforts are under way to facilitate elections, and we are committed to ensuring the polls at the earliest," said Priyank Kharge, rural development and panchayat raj minister. The 5th State Finance Commission (SFC), headed by former Lok Sabha member C Narayanaswamy, issued a stark warning to the state govt about lapsing funds in its first report. The SFC is preparing a second report for the 2025-26 financial year, expected in Dec, to reinforce the urgency of conducting polls."The only way to avail this fund is to ensure pending polls for the local bodies before March 2026. I hope things will fall in place," Narayanaswamy said.For Congress govt, the ZP-TP elections pose significant political risks. Widely regarded as the semi-finals of assembly elections, these cover all districts and could amplify antiincumbency sentiments amid allegations of corruption. BJP, already preparing a strong fight in BBMP elections, is expected to heighten its challenge statewide.On the legal front, the Karnataka State Election Commission (SEC) has filed a contempt petition in the high court against the state govt for failing to notify reservations for ZP-TP constituencies following delimitation. The high court is scheduled to hear the case on Nov 27, while the Supreme Court will address a petition demanding early BBMP elections on Nov 25.“As we have filed a contempt petition against the govt related to ZP-TP polls, we are going to request the high court to pass an urgent order. We’re hopeful of a favourable ruling and are well prepared to conduct the elections at the earliest,” said state election commissioner GS Sangresh.Congress govt, often critical of the BJP-led Union govt for allegedly withholding state’s rightful share of funds, is under immense pressure to expedite these elections. The outcome of the upcoming legal hearings and the govt’s actions will be critical in determining whether Karnataka secures its share of 15th Finance Commission grants.
Article Summary: Karnataka faces a severe financial setback as prolonged delays in elections jeopardize its eligibility for central grants. The state has just 16 months to complete these polls or risk losing a huge share of Rs 18,948 crore allocated by the 15th Finance Commission for 2021-26. The elections for BBMP, pending since Sept 2021, and for ZPs and TPs, overdue since May 2022, remain stalled.

Article Title: Garlic prices go north in Rajasthan, hit Rs 600/kg as rains damage crop
Article Text:
Good crop in Feb expected

JAIPUR: Pungent garlic has gone missing from curries and kitchens in the state as prices for the spice zoomed this month, ranging from Rs 400 to Rs 600 per kg in the retail market.Prolonged monsoon, heavy rains and moisture have damaged the crop in the prime growing areas of Kota, Baran, Bundi and Jodhpur, taking production down. After Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan is the largest producer of garlic."In the wholesale market, we buy garlic in the Rs 250-350/kg range. It's sold at Rs 400-600 in the retail market. Heavy moisture that lasted till mid-Oct has damaged the crop this year," said Shiv Shankar Sharma, a wholesale trader at Muhana Mandi, pointing to the shortage in supply."The supply is almost 40% of what we usually get. The rising trend will continue. However, when we start getting garlic from other states in a week, there will be a minor dip in prices," said Mohammed Qasim, a wholesale dealer of onions, ginger and garlic at the mandi.In Sept, garlic was being sold at Rs 120-160/kg, which rose to Rs 160-240 in Oct."Now the prices are between Rs 400 to 600, depending on the size. While small garlic is available at Rs 400/kg, and the larger ones at Rs 600," said Kishan Samtani, another wholesale dealer. Most traders expect a good crop in Feb. "As per sowing estimates, we expect good production next season," said Yusuf Salim, a wholesaler at a vegetable market in Hasanpura.
Article Summary: Prolonged monsoon, heavy rains and moisture have damaged the crop in prime growing areas of Kota, Baran, Bundi and Jodhpur. After Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan is the largest producer of garlic. Most traders expect a good crop in Feb.

Article Title: Musk: Elon Musk says Twitter in precarious position, defends cost cuts
Article Text:
"I will resign as CEO as soon as I find someone foolish enough to take the job!" Musk said.

SAN FRANCISCO: Elon Musk is defending his massive cost-cutting at Twitter as necessary for the social media platform to survive next year, due in part to debt payments tied to his $44 billion takeover of the company."This company is like, basically, you're in a plane that is headed towards the ground at high speed with the engines on fire and the controls don't work," Musk told a late-night audience on a Twitter Spaces call Tuesday.That's after Elon Musk said earlier on Tuesday that he plans on remaining as Twitter's CEO until he can find someone willing to replace him in the job.Musk's announcement came after millions of Twitter users asked him to step down in an online poll the billionaire himself created and promised to abide by."I will resign as CEO as soon as I find someone foolish enough to take the job!" Musk tweeted. "After that, I will just run the software & servers teams."Since taking over the San Francisco social media platform in late October, Musk's run as CEO has been marked by quickly issued rules and policies that have often been withdrawn or changed soon after being made public.Musk said Tuesday night that he "spent the last five weeks cutting costs like crazy" and trying to build a stronger paid subscription service because otherwise Twitter might be operating with $3 billion in negative cash flow next year. He in part blamed the $12.5 billion in debt tied to his April agreement to buy the company, as well as the Federal Reserve's recent interest rate hikes.Some of Musk's actions have unnerved Twitter advertisers and turned off users. He has laid off more than half of Twitter's workforce, released contract content moderators and disbanded a council of trust and safety advisors that the company formed in 2016 to address hate speech and other problems on the platform.The Tesla CEO has also alienated investors at his electric vehicle company over concerns that Twitter is taking too much of his attention, and possibly offending loyal customers.Even more unnerving for investors, Tesla shares are plummeting.Shares of Tesla are down 35% since Musk took over Twitter on Oct. 27, costing investors billions. Tesla's market value was over $1.1 trillion on April 1, the last trading day before Musk disclosed he was buying up Twitter shares. The company has since lost 58% of its value, at a time when rival auto makers are cutting in on Tesla's dominant share of electric vehicle sales.Shares fell Wednesday, as they have every day this week.A single share of Tesla that cost about $400 to start the year, can now be had for less than $140.Musk sought to defend some of his recent Twitter decisions on the Twitter Spaces call."They may seem sometimes spurious or odd or whatever," Musk said. "It's because we have an emergency fire drill on our hands. That's the reason. Not because I'm naturally capricious. Or at least, aspirationally, I'm not naturally capricious."Musk, who also helms the SpaceX rocket company, has previously acknowledged how difficult it will be to find someone to take over as Twitter CEO .Bantering with Twitter followers earlier this week, he said that the person replacing him "must like pain a lot" to run a company that he said has been "in the fast lane to bankruptcy.""No one wants the job who can actually keep Twitter alive. There is no successor," Musk tweeted.As things stand, Musk would still retain overwhelming influence over platform as its owner. He fired the company's board of directors soon after taking control.
Article Summary: Elon Musk says he plans on remaining as Twitter's CEO until he can find someone willing to replace him in the job. Musk's run as CEO has been marked by quickly issued rules and policies that have often been withdrawn or changed soon after being made public. Musk has laid off more than half of Twitter's workforce, released contract content moderators.

Article Title: Sensex jumps nearly 850 points; Nifty settles at 18,101: Top reasons for market rally
Article Text:
Here are the top reasons for today's market rally:

* IT, Auto stocks shine

* Q3 results season starts

* Positive global cues

* China stocks rise

* Rupee gains

(With inputs from agencies)

NEW DELHI: Equity indices jumped on Monday after declining for previous 3 sessions with the benchmark BSE sensex gaining nearly 850 points amid positive trends in global markets.The 30-share BSE sensex zoomed 846.94 points or 1.41% to settle at 60,747.31. During the day, it jumped 989.04 points or 1.65% to 60,889.41.The broader NSE Nifty climbed 241.75 points or 1.35% to end at 18,101.20.From the sensex pack, Mahindra & Mahindra, HCL Technologies, IndusInd Bank, Tata Consultancy Services, Bharti Airtel, Tech Mahindra, Wipro, Infosys, Reliance Industries and Axis Bank were the major winners.Both indexes posted their biggest intraday gains in nearly two months after logging a weekly loss of over 1% each in the first week of 2023.TCS was 3.4% up ahead of its results, while Titan was the top loser on the Nifty 50, falling 2.1% after the jewellery maker reported quarterly sales growth below expectations.Metals rose 1.43% on hopes of demand recovery after top metals consumer China reopened its borders.Shares of Reliance Industries also witnessed strong buying today as the stock jumped 2.34%."These gains were also absorbed by the domestic market, with IT being the biggest gainer ahead of the release of sector earnings, as the favourable US economy boosted sector optimism," Vinod Nair, Head of Research at Geojit Financial Services told news agency PTI.IT sector stocks advanced 2.83%, making it the best-performing sector among the other 13 major Nifty sectoral indexes.Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) is about to kick off the Q3 results season later today.The quarterly earnings reports of top IT firms Infosys, HCL Tech and Wipro are due later this week.The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed as much as 1.9% on Monday, taking its advance from an Oct. 24 low to more than 20%. Gauges in Hong Kong, Taiwan and South Korea led gains in the session, while Japan was closed for a holiday."Wall Street climbed in anticipation of a less aggressive US Fed as wage growth slowed and service activity contracted, fuelling bets that inflation is moderating.
